body.p: This short guide is meant to offer a general outline of the tasks that should be completed to get the most out of .

section.title: 1. Create Your Account and Organization
section.p: The first thing you need to do is create an account. See for information.

section.title: 2. Install and Configure on Your Server
section.p: This will be done by the Feedback Platform Admin for your organization. See the section for all the details about how to install the service on Linux, setting up a database, and various topics about specific configuration possibilities.

section.title: 2.3. Add the Feedback Commenting Component to Your Website
section.p: See the section to learn how to integrate the Oxygen Feedback commenting component in your WebHelp output or in any HTML-based web page.

section.title: 3.4. Manage in the Administration Interface
section.p: See the section for information about how to moderate comments, manage users, view statistics, and configure various settings, notifications, and other components of the Oxygen Feedback comment system.

section.title: 4.5. Integrate with Oxygen XML Editor/Author
section.p:
See the topic for information about how to integrate Oxygen Feedback with Oxygen XML Editor/Author so that your documentation team can see all the comments added in your WebHelp output.

section.title: Other Common Tasks
section.p: Here is a list of references about how to perform some of the other most common tasks for new users:

dlentry.dt: How to edit your organization's profile
dlentry.dd: The organization Owner can edit and manage various facets of the organization from the Organization Profile page. For example, you can change the name, home URL, contact email, or logo, configure legal policies, or delete an organization.
The organization Owner can choose who to invite to join the organization and they can specify and manage the user roles for all members of the organization from the Members page.

Users with the role of organization Owner, Admin, or Moderator can view, manage, and moderate comments added in the output from the Comments page. For example, you can filter, accept, reject, purge, or resolve comments.
